subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: John: I did not mean to imply that Wells had all the answers, merely that he appears to be an acknowledged expert in the field, which I am not, and I was
messageBody:
John:

I did not mean to imply that Wells had all the answers, merely that he appears to be an acknowledged expert in the field, which I am not, and I was passing on what he told me regarding the substitution of "chr" for "tr."

I have not looked at the lexical sets you have been writing about, but since Wells invented them, I assume there is no set which includes that substitution.  Do you have any reason to suspect that a significant proportion of any speech population anywhere makes this substitution?   Can you point me to a dictionary that lists the substitution as an accepted pronunciation for "train"?

The point I was getting at is that although there is a tremendous variation in spoken English from one dialect to another, there is a distinction which I feel needs to be made between spelling according to one's dialect and spelling according to a speech pathology (if that is the appropriate term), such as a lisp.  Do people who speak with a lisp hear their lisp or not?  I would think if they don't hear it, they would have no reason to write it into a QS word since they would think they spoke like everyone else in their area and the rest of the people aren't lisping.  If they do hear it in their own speech, then they should realize that isn't the way everyone else speaks in their area, so they should be able to avoid including an oddity of their own idiolect in their QS.

Paige

John Cowan wrote:

Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> I recently inquired of John C. Wells, a linguist who lectures at
> University College in London,

And inventor of the lexical sets I have been talking about, by the way.

> According to him, this is not a known dialect from any geographical
> region, but is, apparently, a peculiarity of some people's speech, and I
> suspect a very small percentage of English speakers do this.

Wells said it, I believe it, that settles it!

But there is plenty of variation around words like "tune";
some say "toon", some "tyoon", and some "choon".

--

the friskiest group around -- comes from cowan@...
forever being on the qui vive for the sound http://www.ccil. org/~cowan
of jack-booted fascism coming down the pike. --Molly Ivins
